did.abstract: This collection consists of correspondence, photographs, ephemera and sheet music belonging to New York publicity agent Bernard Green. The bulk is correspondence related to a book Green had hoped to publish, but which he never completed.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Bernard "Bernie" Green was born in the Bronx in 1908. His family name was Greenberg, but he used the name Green professionally. He married Ann Shulman in 1941, making a living working as a publicity agent for a theatrical company.

In his later years, Green began preparations for a book he hoped to publish. He envisioned a collection of anecdotes by celebrities (many of whom he knew personally) about their mothers, and sent out letters requesting material from comedians, actresses, scientists, politicians, and other notable people. The replies he received make up much of this collection. The project was never completed, however, and Green died in June 1983.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The bulk of the Bernard Green collection is correspondence. Green was in the exploratory stages of writing a book of favorite stories by notable people about their mothers, and much of the correspondence relates to that project. Other highlights from the collection include a program from the "roasting" of Ed Sullivan by the Friars Club, sheet music, and a scrapbook of Green's column in the Brooklyn Daily Eagle.

userestrict.p: While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Gift of Janice Greenberg, the daughter-in-law of Bernard Green.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in three series by format. Within each series, the arrangement is chronological.
